abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Public Sector Reform
            and Capacity Building Project for Cape Verde are as follows:
            the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability was
            unlikely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory and the borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory. The lessons learned indicate
            that while Cape Verde has shown better implementation
            effectiveness than many other African countries, there is a
            limit to how much more can be delivered with the existing
            capacity. The Bank should therefore guard against
            overestimating the borrower's capacity to implement.
            Specifically, project designs should be simple. The
            components should reflect only the highest priorities of the
            government and not lump together all desirable public sector
            issues to be resolved in one project in a country where
            implementation capacity is limited. Ensuring ownership and
            commitment of the borrower is a recurring theme in Bank
            projects. It remains very difficult to ascertain ownership
            and commitment beyond the desire of most borrowers to obtain
            needed funds for projects. The relatively better job
            conditions offered by the PIU in comparison to the public
            sector made its staffing vulnerable to political
            intervention. When implementing a Public Sector Reform
            Project that may be politically sensitive and can have
            adverse social implications for public service employees,
            special attention should be paid to the timing of
            implementation of the project in relation to the political
            electoral cycles of the country. For such a project, a
            significant period of implementation should not coincide
            with the election period.
